results.title: C News focus: Monday 22 May 2006
results.brief_description: Private lives of public figures. Aired 22 May 2006 this episode focuses on the media, and their coverage of the private lives of public figures. Independent MP Andrew Olexander is interviewed on what it feels like to be the subject of such scrutiny.

results.title: Plug-in. Episode 2
results.creator_credit: Salvador Castro, Simon Moule and C31 Melbourne
results.brief_description: Aired 07 April 2005. Plug-in is a fifteen minute television program that aired weekly on channel 31 in 2005 (season 2 scheduled from July 2006) . Each fifteen minutes consisted of a major and minor documentary as well as a vox pop montage relating to the major piece. Within this framework a broad range of material is presented, from profiles of the day-to-day workings of community organizations to documentaries and political animation. Plug-in presents material on indigenous rights and reconciliation, migrant issues, environment, education, health, culture, arts and dissent. In 2005 Plug In TV won 2 Antenna Awards (Australian Community Television Awards) for best editing, and best sound and was nominated for best show of the year.

results.title: Salam Cafe. Episode 13 (Season  2)
results.creator_credit: Ahmed Hassan, Jehed Dabab and C31 Melbourne
results.brief_description: ‘Salam Café has no group or organisational affiliation - we’re just a group of mates who thought it might be good to give Melbourne a window on everyday Muslims, and have fun at the same time!’ In this episode Salam Cafe 2 Go visit the MCG on the Grand Final day. The panel interview Qamar Atosh, the National Winner of the YAMY award. Along with our previous guest Monique to discuss the YAMY night. In the absense of Susan, her husband Waleed reveals the winner of the photo comp. We hear about the recent Declaration of Faith Based Schools drafted by representatives of Christian, Jewish and Islamic Colleges.

results.title: C31: Season 50 presentation
results.brief_description: A montage of clips from the history of C 31 - Melbourne’s community TV station. Established in 1994, C31 gained a full license in 2002 and now attracts over 1 million viewers every month. This montage was produced to celebrate the 50th 13 season broadcast and presents some of the breadth and diversity of C31 programming, as well as a potted history of the station and its achicevements over the last 12 years.

results.title: The Pub
results.brief_description:
Annabel spent the first 7 years of her life living above her parent’s pub. She reminisces about all the adventures had by her and her siblings as they run amok in their unconventional playground.
You can create your own Digital Story. Ask at the Information Desk or visit www.acmi.net.au/digitalstorytelling

results.title: Small towns, big picture: a journey in building community
results.creator_credit: Maureen Rogers, Philip Ashton, Judy Spokes and Image Link
results.brief_description:
Five country towns in Central Victoria - Dunolly,
Wedderburn, Carisbrook, Maldon and Talbot - have been
involved in a social experimental project called “Small Towns Big Picture” for the last two years or more with the
Centre for Sustainable Regional Communities, La Trobe
University, Bendigo under the leadership of Dr Maureen
Rogers. Concern was being expressed about the demise of small country towns and their future, economically,
socially and environmentally and the main intention of the
Project was to develop a toolkit for measuring the “health” of a community - a benchmark for sustainability. With the assistance of Judy Spokes and the Cultural Development Network seven artists were commissioned to work with the communities and the researchers. Workshops were established incorporating the community, including the Energy Footprint Project and a Community Cohesion Project. Craig Christie (playwright) has been working on creating and producing a musical play in Carisbrook capturing the issues from the Community Cohesion focus group and auditioning the local
communities to perform in the play. This documentary
provides an inside view of the workings of “Small Towns Big Picture” and includes interviews with artists, project
leaders, councillors, teachers and members of the
community.
results.title_for_label: Small towns, big picture: a journey in building community

results.title: Juggling the elements
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Katrina Sawyer, Tracey Power, Stewart Lodge and Sakshi Productions
results.brief_description: Tracey Power has maintained her courage, honesty and humour despite having suffered abuse and trauma at the hands of her family and the state from birth. Tracey looks different, she sometines has a shaved head and many tattoos and she is scarred from ‘slashing up’. Tracey acts differently, she doesn’t follow the social rules of behaviour. She loves trams and has the word ‘tram’ tattooed on her hand. She has a mental illness which has led her to being institutuionalised a number of times. She is both street wise and disarmingly trusting and generous. She looks very tough, yet she is very sensitive and vulnerable. She tells her story ‘in your face’ and she tells it ‘straight’ about abuse, institutions, drug addiction, mental illness, slashing up, giving up her baby for adoption and also about friendships, fun, love and hope. Tracey’s story tells us alot about living with mental illness, about being different and about surviving without losing your spirit or humanity.

results.title: Roar culture
results.brief_description:
‘Roar culture’ is a successful six month community arts project that was documented on video. The project brought together schools, community groups, artists, people from culturally diverse backgrounds and local government, including over 80 students, 10 storytellers, and 14 artists/mentors. ‘Roar culture’ explores issues of identity concerning ethnic, religious & sexual discrimination, cultural diversity and tolerance.
In doing so, it was critical to the process that there was a space for understanding and insight: a space where the many faces and voices which contribute to Bendigo’s historical and contemporary image and identity, were paid attention.
Stage one: the project’s starting point was the narrative or story. Stories from 10 multicultural & indigenous individuals whose memories ranged from the 1930s through to today, from places and countries which hauntingly navigated us to Bendigo. Each told a different story about living in regional Victoria however the threads of isolation, language difficulties, fragmented families and broader cultural or religious differences provided significant links.
Stage two was a mentor program, which furthered the developed the artistic skills of the students through a variety of cultural & arts mediums. These included workshops exploring Aboriginal dance; Japanese movement and theatre; contemporary and traditional music from a cross section of cultures; photojournalism and visual art mediums.
Stage three included a series of round table discussions and practical workshops uniting the stories of Stage One with the skills development of Stage Two. This enabled scripts & a musical score to be written for the final stage.
Stage four included performance rehearsals & backstage skills development which culminated in an experimental performance through multi-disciplined artforms in the round at The Capital Theatre on July 16 &17 1999.
Participating in this project were students & teachers from Bendigo Senior Secondary College with members of the stage design crew from Girton Grammar School and Catholic College. An original score of music was composed by local musicians and performed by the Bendigo Youth Orchestra. Financial partners were City of Greater Bendigo, Festivals Australia, The Myer Foundation & Victorian Multicultural Commission.
‘Roar culture’ was awarded the 1999 Local Government & the Arts Leadership Award for Best Practice Management of a Cultural Project

Lynda Newton
Project & Artistic Director

results.title: Woomera 2002
results.creator_credit: Laurel Heisman, Anthony Snowden and SKA TV
results.brief_description: During Easter 2002, activists from around Australia converged upon Woomera Detention Centre to protest the federal government’s mandatory detention of refugees. Activists coordinated with the detainees’ protests within the detention centre, resulting in the mass breakout of 50 refugees. Most of the escapees were returned to the detention centre, but 11 detainees achieved freedom. The activists continued to protest the inhumane treatment of refugees in detention throughout the weekend, expressing their solidarity with both the detained refugees and also the people that escaped. This incident led to an increase in global awareness surrounding mandatory detention policies in Australia
